author: capnrex
title: The Mexican
review:
The Parts - The parts in this set are fantastic, we have the lovely sombrero with some small details around the brim, which is very big (about the size of a fifty pence piece if you live in the UK or Cad Bane's hat if you have a set with him in it). His head has a large moustache and a large smile which looks very good. The poncho is made up of two sections of material, one for the front and one for the back which are highly decorated, sadly the torso underneath the poncho is unprinted but you don't really see that area anyway! The maracas are also detailed with some patterning around the top of them, they look quite realistic and you get a spare one with the figure (so you get three). Finally there are the legs which are just plain old brown.

 

The Figure - I see this figure as being very nice for display and to play with, you could even make yourself an entire Mexican band with multiples of this figure! You could also harvest it for parts with that sombrero, the poncho and the maracas all being very desirable.

 

Overall - I have to give this figure 9/10. I only knock a point off because it unfortunately has no printing on his torso, which would have been nice, but still it is a wonderful figure!

author: absolutelylez
title: One of the best figures in Series two. Lots of unique parts!
review:
Let me start from the top!

The sombrero is of course a new unique mould, and very large, about 4x4 studs in size (!)
It has very nice golden printings on the edge of the hat.
It is easy to remove, and clutches incredibly comfortable on the head.
The clutching mechanism is primitive and quite ugly but does the job well.

The head - nice big moustache. Can't say any more!

The torso is plain and unprinted. A printed torso would have been super to use in many ways, native south american dress, or even for red indians, etc.

The poncho makes up for it. It is very colourful and well designed to covery much of the torso.

The maracas are unique and have good quality green printing on them. An improvement could have been made by putting a bead in each maraca to make them shake. I guess this would have been expensive and difficult though.

author: A_Brickset_user
title: Ay Caramba! A Great Minifig!
review:
LEGO Minifigures series two definitely brings some detailed minifigures to the LEGO world. The mariachi band member is no exception.

Building Experience: Same as all the CMs: simple.

Parts: A wealth of new pieces, including maracas, a green sombrero (with printed gold S's all around), and a poncho. The face suits the minifig quite well. The torso is plain and boring, but the colorful poncho covers it up.

Playability: Not much, I suppose. More of a collector's item, though perfect for kids who love minifigures.

Value for Money: A steal for just $2-3.

Final Thoughts: This is a great minifigure. It is one of the gems of Series 2. Wherever you may find it, buy it (by using Brickset's excellent barcode sheet, of course). Thanks for reading my first review!

author: BrickManBrick
title: Mexican sumbrero
review: I love this guy. The hat is awesome the poncho is nice! I got by using the iphone to know that was him at my local toysrus for 2.50$!! Great little buy. Very creative outfit. I have most of the others to. Out of all of them all. Nice fig!!

author: tyuku57
title: mexican madness
review:
The mexican is a minifigure with a lot of playability but not everything can be perfect.

While i accept that the poncho has colour and is very nice the torso is only one colour and the legs are the same. I do however like the maracas which suit it very nicely and the unique hat is brilliant with the gold round its side. overall i think this is a great minifigure with great money value. I hope this review was helpful!

author: legoman357
title: mexicano marracas
review:
the mexican is the second best minifigure ( the best being the spartan) and i was overjoyed with it when i first got it. It has a variety of rare pieces the poncho marracas and sombraro are the first of their kind.

Pros: the poncho , sombraro , marracas and face

 

Cons: the body has no decal

author: Carl
title: Mariachi
review: The Mariachi, or 'Mr Maracas' as I call him is a truly amazing minifig. His maracas are cool and his new green sombrero is AWESOME. The Mexican spirit has been captured perfectly by the LEGO designers and overall the Mariachi is my third favourite of Series 2. Despite his overaall awesomeness,  he is only a minifig so there isn't much in the way of playability or building experience. I got series 1 and 2 for Christmas, which hopefully explains why I rated value for money 5/5. Overall 'Mr Maracas' is a great addition to any minifig collection and I recommend him to all.

author: Firox_5000
title: Mexicana omega
review:
i found this figure when getting this during a 3 for 2 offer at Argos. the figure contains 8 pieces and takes no longer than 2 minutes to build.

 

The figure contains some very unique and cool pieces, A large sombero hat with amazing gold printing,some printed maraca's and a poncho with patterns al over.

 

This figure is one the best in series 2 and I recomend him alot.

 

playability is quite good , you can make him encounter cowboys,play his maraca's or just play around with the other ones in the series.

 

This figure goes well with lego cowboy western sets, a mexican restaurant and any lego city.

author: CharlieTheFunEngine
title: TinyTurbosCityAndToyStory Reviews Episode 18: Mariachi
review:
"LEGO mexicana? Mi quincuagésimo juego de LEGO."

The Mariachi was my third Collectable Minifigure from Series 2 and my 50th LEGO set. If it weren't for the poncho he'd be the best of Series 2. Until I opened the packet I thought he was the Pop Star as his maraca felt like a microphone, but I'm kind of glad it wasn't.

Building Experience:

It's a minifigure, can't expect too much.

Parts:

Like all of the Collectable Minifigures the face is brand new. The sombrero is utterly huge and the black stand is quite useful. The problem I have is the lack of torso printing, which has been substituted by a poncho. It's realistic but I was disappointed to find that it's two pieces of fabric when I was expecting a plastic piece like the armor on some of the knights in Castle sets from 2004-2006.

Playability:

Not fantastic, but then none of these minifigures are. They're really more for display purposes.

Value for Money:

I paid AUD$3.75 for this Minifigure and when you factor in the new face and sombrero, that's exactly right.

Overall:

It would have been the best Collectable Minifigure in my collection if his poncho was plastic, but he does look fantastic. Hours of fun, maybe.

author: Andabain
title: Nice hat!
review: This minifigure is awsome. The best part by far is the sombrero. The cloth on him has a neat design as well. And the maraccas just add that little pizzaz to the minifig. A great buy in my opinion!

author: kaptainkool
title: Awesome figure
review: This figure is my favorite for the features that are provided. You get a green sombrero that is new with gold printing that you could use for a bandito, along with the poncho, and then just add some pistols. the head was uniquely printed with a big mustache on his face which you could use to substitute for the musketeer in series 4, or a chef. I see that some people on the internet put the poncho on wrong, so do me a solid and put the poncho on right. You put the back part on first, and then the first part. the maracas are new and have green printing. thank you for your time.

author: tkettle9719
title: Mariachi Perfection!
review:
I got this set from my parents' trip, and think that this is the most stereotypical, greatest minifig Lego has ever made.

Pros

  • -Excellent pieces everywhere.
  • -Sombrero is among the greatest pieces, and is a perfect pair with the head.
  • …

Cons

  • -Torso is a tad uninspired.
  • -Wish it had a trumpet instead.
  • …
This is so stereotypically funny, which makes this guy great. Get it NOW (and I stress it) because it is that great.

author: 1UPminifig
title: Mariachi Now Playing At All Taco Tuesdays!
review:
Introduction

The Mariachi Guy was one of the first Collectible Minifigures that I got when I just started collecting them a couple of years back; when Series 2 was around. Since the Lego Movie line premiered, the Taco Man rehashed many of the pieces from Mariachi Guy with some color changes - it seems as if LEGO will be releasing a recolored version of all the collectible minifigures in time - I thought I’d take a look back at the original.

Polybag/Instructions

This series’ polybag has a pretty light blue colour that’s very attractive to the eye, unlike some of the other series polybags which (in my humble opinion) had truly ghastly colors (I’m looking at you Series 4!) Right under our beloved LEGO logo - and the silver & red lettering announcing Minifigures! - we’re introduced to LEGO’s choice picks seeking our attention and gleeful curiosity. Luckily our Mariachi Guy got front billing, only second to the power-punch Karate Master.      

Something which I really love about the polybag - that may be overlooked (just noticing it now) - is the question marks aligning with the top rim of the bag, signaling that our beloved bags are a random grab bag – so if you didn’t already know, you’re in for a surprise (and possibly some duplicates). So, be prepared, you never know what you’re gonna get (unless, of course, you have magic fingers and a lot of time on your hands to feel up the bags). Beyond the little preview, piece count, and a warning, there isn’t more than that to polybags.

The instructions sheet is the very brief, as you would expect from a set that only consists of a lone minifigure, so there’s not much to say. On the first side of the instruction sheet, we are shown how to a build minifigure for those who don’t already know, along with column list of body parts and accessories from Series 2. On the reverse side we have a simple checklist showing all the minifigures of the series -which I personally found helpful before discovering Brickset.Com.

 Building

For the most part the build of this minifigure is easy - like any other minifig - but the poncho does offer a challenge for those with stubby fingers or dexterity issues. LEGO ponchos are cloth pieces, (really just two capes) and you’ll have to align the holes of the fabric right on top of each other in order to put them on the “neck” of the Lego man (of whom is briefly beheaded). It sounds simple, then you try it, followed by several attempts. There is no shame in asking someone for help, especially if that person is a pro at threading a needle or excellent repairing with superglue.   

Minifigure

Helmet/Hair: With Mariachi Guy’s headwear, we get what appears to have once been an exclusive mold for his green sombrero. The brim of the hat is wavy, the front being higher than the back, a nice detail to give some real world likeness. A minor detail to the brim is a little gold pattern running across the hat, breaking up the green monotone. An unassuming detail are the small indents near the top of the sombrero, helping to complete the hat shape. I’m a big fan of the sombrero and I would say it’s one of my favorite hat pieces.

Head: The face for me is the true highlight of Mariachi Guy; I just love everything about it! He’s got black arched eyebrows that frame is face quite nicely, having one of the few eyebrows LEGO designed to stand out. The eyes are basic minifigure fare (two black dots) and not anything special, but there is always something so loveable and cute about these sorts of Town minifigure eyes. Mariachi Guy has a rockin’ black bandito mustache that I fell in love with immediately - it’s just a perfect fit. To finish off an already awesome face, we get a wonderful gleeful grin.

Torso: The torso of Mariachi Guy is unassuming, comprising of a plain gray chest with tan arms. I suppose with the poncho covering up the torso, there wasn’t much need to invest in a shirt. The multi-colored (tan, green and red patterns) on the poncho make up for the simple underside, as there is considerable detail in the cloth print.  

Legs: Nothing special here, just standard brown legs. Even though the poncho adds flair, as I have seen some pretty outstanding leg prints from this line I can’t help but feel a little disappointed there weren’t anything special included here.

Accessories: The accessories we get with Mariachi Guy are two red/green maracas (of course!) with a complimentary pattern to the poncho. I don’t have much to say about them, they’re just simple and fun, but sadly they do not rattle. As is typical, the small black display stand piece is included.

Playability

This guy - like a lot of the collectable minifigures - has rather scarce playability. Arms go up, arms go down. Etc. Mariachi Guy is perfect for all sets depicting a vacation; festivities (Mexican fiesta anyone?), beach scenes, etc.  I’d like to see someone put him to good use in a fan Brick movie, complete with sound effects.

Suggested Pairings

A good pair up with Mariachi Guy would be with his (obviously) long lost twin brother Taco Guy (from the LEGO movie minifigure series).Also, set #850449: Minifigure Accessory Pack has a beach party set-up and I could easily see some mariachi music helping Hula Girl swing her hips. Maybe LEGO will release a Mexican restaurant eventually, or a taco food truck! (Taco Tuesday’s anyone?)

Conclusion

In conclusion the Mariachi Guy is a unique minifigure, but he sadly has little support in the LEGO environments to not leave him somewhat out of place in the mainstream LEGO society. While I do find some of his features lacking, he has one off my all-time favorite faces and a very cool hat, I give this set a 4 out of 5.

Tip: When looking for him try feeling for the sombrero and then the maracas

author: sideswinger
title: One of the best!
review:
So the first figure in the LEGO Minifigures Series 2 is the Mariachi or, most commonly called, Maraca Man. And I love this figure, so let's take a closer look!

On top we have that green sombrero, which was new for the figure. It is a great piece too, and it looks especially neat in green. Nice printing all around the top too. It's just a marvellous piece, and I love how it came out.

He also does have a very nice face, with that exaggerated mustache, and his chipper smile looks great as well. No alternate facial expression, which is normal for 2010.

And skipping his poncho, we have his torso, which is pretty plain. It's just a plain light gray color, with no printing on the front or back. I do kind of wish they would have done that, but oh well. His arms are a different color than his body though, to where that are that light brown color.

Ad since his legs are plain brown with no printing, lets talk about his accessories, which are very great. First he has those two identical poncho pieces, which have an excellent pattern on them. It just looks awesome, and is highly detailed for 2010. Then he has those two maraca pieces as well, which also looks amazing. They were new for the figure, and they have the best detail for the maraca piece ever, in my opinion, to where it is just that nice green pattern which go 360 around them both. Just some great accessories.

And my overall opinion, is that this is an excellent figure for 2010, and it's especially great for two bucks. He's also my favorite figure in Series 2. With that being said, the Taco Tuesday Guy in the LEGO Movie Series is, in my opinion, a lot better. I also think the Series 16 Mariachi is a better figure. However, I do like him a lot better than the Series 20 Pinata Boy. He's also still my favorite in the series. And I think that wraps up this review! So check out my Series 1 reviews, and hopefully this helped you decide whether you wanted to buy it off Ebay, and thanks for reading!
